review.title: A framework: Cluster detection and multidimensional visualization of automated data mining using intelligent agents
review.abstract: Data Mining techniques plays a vital role like extraction of required knowledge, finding unsuspected information to make strategic decision in a novel way which in term understandable by domain experts. A generalized frame work is proposed by considering non - domain experts during mining process for better understanding, making better decision and better finding new patters in case of selecting suitable data mining techniques based on the user profile by means of intelligent agents. KEYWORDS: Data Mining Techniques, Intelligent Agents, User Profile, Multidimensional Visualization, Knowledge Discovery.

metadata.title: A FRAMEWORK: CLUSTER DETECTION AND MULTIDIMENSIONAL VISUALIZATION OF AUTOMATED DATA MINING USING INTELLIGENT AGENTS

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijaia.2012.3110 125Data mining techniques play a critical role such as extracting the necessary knowledge and finding unexpected information to make strategic decisions in a new way that is understandable to domain experts in the long term. A general framework work is proposed by taking into account experts outside the domain during the mining process for better understanding, to make better decisions and, if appropriate data mining techniques are selected based on user profiles using intelligent agents, to find better patterns.

sections.heading: KEYWORDS:
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Data Mining Techniques, Intelligent Agents, User Profile, Multidimensional Visualization, Knowledge Discovery.
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The problem is how to maintain this data and also the extraction of the required knowledge. Data mining techniques can be considered as the result of the natural evaluation of information technology. [12] It is the process of analyzing the observational data that allows you to find further unexpected relationships and summarize the data in a novel way that is both understandable and useful to use the user's data, which is called data mining. [12] It is the achievement of relevant knowledge that allows you to make strategic decisions that allow you to move forward. Techniques used in data mining are more difficult to understand than the general user. [13] A system that performs the process autonomously needs more user interaction by selecting the appropriate attribute. Automated data mining technologies minimize this problem by selecting attributes. It also selects the best data mining technique for extraction.

sections.heading: 3.1 Need of the Approach for the Proposed Framework
sections.text: The development of a user-friendly data mining system with intelligent agents through an automated approach is the objective function of this mining technique. It is mainly about developing a neutral system using known data mining techniques. Intelligent agents are also used in the above techniques to implement the automated process. [35] The automated system developed receives the input values of the user and selects the appropriate data mining techniques with the required parameters through the use of intelligent agents. [30] The system also recognizes the quality of clusters in terms of user profile. Finally, the newly gained knowledge shows after selecting suitable visualization techniques. The user agent is used to navigate the user data.

sections.heading: Proposed Methodology
sections.text: Figure4a. Approach to proposed methodologies5.Intelligence AgencyArtificial intelligence and agent systems have been closely linked for several decades [15] [17] [6] [37]. Artificial intelligence is the study of components intelligence, but agents deal with the integration of these components. Agent is therefore defined as a unit that vaguely uses software that uses artificial intelligence techniques to help a human user of a particular application [11] [30] [8] [27] [33]. According to the definition of agents, agents have the following characteristics: 1. Agents are autonomous: operate without direct control with the user and other agents. 2. Agents are also referred to as social communicators among agents. 3. Agents move themselves towards their defined goal.

sections.heading: 5.1 User Interface Agent
sections.text: The user interface agent interacts with the user to help him perform data analysis and data mining activities [35] [10] [15] [24]. The user can provide a general description of the problem at hand in terms of high-level objectives and objectives or provide specific details about the data analysis or mining task to be performed. Step 1: Starting Step 2: Navigation of the user profile. Step 3: Developing a suitable procedure for the intelligent agents to interact with the user profile and cluster techniques. Step 4: Selecting suitable clustering techniques. Algorithm selection. (Priority, Ranking) Step 5: Designing an appropriate procedure for cluster detection Step 5: Designing an appropriate procedure for the software agent to select the appropriate visualization tool. Step 6: Multi-dimensional visualization of results.Step 7: Stop

sections.heading: Developed Procedure for User Interface Agent
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.2 Ranking Agent
sections.text: Once the user preference is determined, the ranking agent helps ranking the attributes. The ranking is based on a number of factors such as query weight, storage space, attribute type properties, and object similarity [29]. The highest-rated attributes are taken for clustering.

sections.heading: Developed Procedure for Ranking Agent

sections.heading: 5.3 Data Mining Agent
sections.text: The Data Mining Agent implements specific data mining methods and algorithms. The Data Mining Agent contains specific cluster algorithms that have been implemented in-house and may have been installed within the environment [2] [23] [36]. Thus, the Data Mining Agent is responsible for performing the actual data mining activity and generating the results.

sections.heading: Developed Procedure for Data Mining Agent
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.4 Visualization Agent
sections.text: In order to assess the effectiveness of visualization techniques, the way they support and complement the data mining process needs to be understood. [23] [36] The relationship between data mining and visualization process can be explained with few conditions. Data set visualization can be defined as a combination of different methods or user priority over an approach of selecting and specifying the patterns to be displayed. It is one of the interesting techniques for determining which visualization techniques are better than those used to improve visualization techniques. Visualization provides the user with more added value for a simple understanding and also increases the ability to understand the final results [19].

sections.heading: Developed Procedure for Visualization Agent
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6. PROPOSED FRAME WORK FOR AUTOMATED DATA MINING USING INTELLIGENT AGENTS
sections.text: From this framework, the automated data mining system receives the necessary data from the given database. In addition to obtaining data from the given database, it also obtains the user information (new or old user). The developed system selects the appropriate data mining techniques, which are provided on the basis of the objective functions. The algorithm considered in this developed system is the partitioning of algorithms. At the same time, if the user has already used the automated data mining system, the results are recorded by the intelligent agent and stored in the database. The end result is also transmitted by the intelligent agent to the next user. This makes the agent technology more user-friendly. Intelligent agents are used in the automated process of attribute selection, ranking process, clustering, cluster detection and visualization. The user interagent is responsible for receiving data from the specified user agent and the specifications.

sections.heading: 6.1 User Interface Agent
sections.text: The automated system is executed by navigating and analyzing the user profile [38]. Based on the user behavior with the data mining system and also by locating the (new or existing) user profile, the productive attributes are degraded by the user agent through the data mining agent, where the actual mining process takes place. User identification is based on the selection of data sets such as number of records, number of attributes, data types, etc. The user interface agent analyzes all information related to the user behavior and transfers control to the data mining agent for further processing. 6.2 The data mining agent has two main roles: Clustering and clustering based on the parameters of the user profile agent.

sections.heading: 6.2a Cluster Formations
sections.text: Clustering is defined as grouping objects that are similar within the same cluster and dissimilar to objects with other clusters. Partitioning is considered as clustering of different types of attributes, numerical and categorical data. Clustering is also done depending on the dataset, data size and data types. Data Mining Agent selects the appropriate cluster algorithm for better cluster formation.

sections.heading: 6.2b Cluster Detections
sections.text: Data Mining Agent is used here to analyze the quality of formulated clusters based on quality parameters. Generally, cluster algorithms generate clusters based on input data. But all clusters are not good clusters. Intelligent Agent in the automated system is used to find the good clusters between different clusters.

sections.heading: 6.3 Visualization Agent
sections.text: The visualization can be 1D, 2D or 3D, based on the type of cluster literature (numerical or categorical). In general, the most important difficult task in data mining is to create reports that should be comprehensible to all users. Manually, it is possible to create reports, but it is difficult to justify the report at any time. Under these aspects, an automated system is used to create reports based on cluster literature, regardless of time and data. In this work, the visualization agent coordinates with the data mining agent, based on identifying suitable visual methods for each specific cluster.

sections.heading: 7. DATA BASED CONSIDERED
sections.text: The data set used in this research paper is a student database containing 50,000 data sets of different data types. The data types considered in this paper are numerical data and categorical data. It contains almost 40 attributes of different data types. Some of the attributes used in our research are REG _ NO, NAME, YEAR, SEMESTER, ASSIG _ PARAMETER, MAX _ MARK, MIN _ MARK, LIB _ ACCNO, ISSUE _ DATE, RETURN _ DATA, ACC _ NO, SPECIALIZATION, STREET _ NO, STREET _ NO, PLACE,

sections.heading: COUNTRY, MODULE_CODE, TUTOR_NAME, EMAIL_ID, TEL_PHONE, SESSION, PASS_PERCENTAGE, AVG_INT, AVG_EXT, AVG_TOT.
sections.text: This year, it has reached the point where it will be able to retaliate.

sections.heading: AUTHOR PROFILES:
sections.text: Jayabrabu R holds a Master's degree in Computer Science and Application from Pondicherry University, Pondicherry, India, in 2004, and a Master of Philosophy degree from Annamalai University, Chidhambaram, Tamil Nadu, India, in 2007. He is a research scientist at Bharathiar University, Coimbatore, India, and works as an associate professor. His areas of interest are intelligent agents, data analysis, and clustering. Dr. V. Saravanan received his doctorate in 2004 from Bharathiar University, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, India. He has produced 3 PhD students. He has published articles in 15 international journals. His fields of interest include data mining and software agencies. Dr. K.Vivekanandan holds a Ph.D. in Computer Science from Bharathiar University, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, India, in 1996. He has published articles in 17 international journals. His fields of interest include systems and data processing.

A generalized frame work is proposed by considering non – domain experts during mining process for better understanding, making better decision and better finding new patters in case of selecting suitable data mining techniques based on the user profile by means of intelligent agents.
